Recent:

Day 40 - WordsU's Sell Video

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Words U is an auto thesaurus for your phone. On their site, they have a short sell video, the beginning of which is a title slide that says the length of it.

Why it’s good: This sort of tiny detail is so helpful in our cross device and attention starved world. Vimeo’s time badge is easy to miss, especially on mobile. WordsU calling it out on the title slide ensures that I’ll know it isn’t a 5 minute tutorial, so I can punch in and out quickly.

Day 39 - Google Now's Suggested Actions

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When you make reminders in Google Now, it will try to find relevant web content based off of the reminder.

Why it’s good: I often joke that Google is constantly testing the line between helpful and creepy. In this case, I had asked it to remind me to cancel Spotify when I had arrived at home, and it found the relevant article in Spotify’s help.

I’m not entirely sure how it triggers (and really that’s the failing in this design, it’s amazing, how do I replicate it!?) but considering how bang on the suggestion is, I highly approve.

Day 38 - Ommwriter's Environment

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Ommwriter was one of the first of a breed of “distraction free” writing utilities. When you load it up, it takes over your full screen and darkens any secondary montiors.

Why it’s good: Ommwriter’s environment is carefully considered. It doesn’t allow you to use multiple windows. It shuts down your secondary monitor. It plays a series of serene, instrumental songs. It has no text formatting. It gives you 3 font options.

It strips away distractions and forces you to focus on the work at hand. Its lack of compromise is what makes it useful, I could use so many other programs for the same concept. When the going gets tough though, nothing shuts out the clutter as well.

Day 37 - Google Translate for Japanese

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When translating Japanese text, Google Translate has you take a picture of it and then highlight the text with a finger.

Why it’s good: I have always communicated with a roman alphabet. I have no idea how to get a Japanese keyboard, or how to use it once I had it. How then do I enter in my Japanese characters for translation?

Enter Google Translate. I have literally no idea how I would have bridged this gap without this functionality. I don’t exactly know what purpose the highlighting holds, but as soon as you start working with it, it’s incredibly clear.

Side Note on Translation Quality: Yes, it’s not great. I used it to translate the instructions for a Japanese Water Stone I bought off of Amazon, and while broken and bizarre, I understood it well enough to have a santoku knife that I can now shave with. Brilliant!

Day 36 - Spotify's Discover Weekly

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Every Monday, Spotify gives me 30 songs in a playlist based off of things that it thinks I’ll like.

Why it’s good: Do you remember the magical, early days of Pandora? The simple idea that you could listen to a radio station based off of a song or artist you enjoyed was revolutionary. It had its flaws though, the most crucial of which I wryly nicknamed “Pandora Decay,” where your favorite station, if left untended, would slowly wander away from its intended seed until you didn’t even recognize its starting point anymore. You could manage it with carefully tending the stream, thumbsing up and down songs and moving them to different stations, but in the end that was just more work. I wasn’t looking for something to tend, I just wanted music that I like.

Discover Weekly is a different idea in a similar space. Spotify sees what you listen to, so it reaches across the breadth of your taste from your listening and picks songs that it thinks that you’ll like. It averages about a 50% hit rate for me; Half the time I enjoy the song and save it. (as you can see in the screenshot) By comparison, Spotify’s radio function gets about 30%, even with careful curation.

The beauty of this is in its unassuming nature. The songs are just there, not a radio station I’m not allowed to browse through, but a playlist—a mixtape from a friend. I’m not the only one to feel this way about it. Injecting it into the existing feature, playlists, gets me more intwined with a powerful feature, playlists are meant to be shared. They’re the new mixtape! Not only that, but as I learn that Spotify will literally find me music without me asking, it reenforces their value proposition. I don’t just want to keep paying for Spotify so I can listen to Bell Biv Devoe 15 times in a row, I also now am counting on it noticing and giving me some other early 90’s hip hop.

Day 35 - Treehouse's Module Nav

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When inside of a Treehouse Module, a small navigation shows you the content for the entire module.

Why it’s good: Treehouse is designed to keep you just outside of your comfort zone, so they do a lot to help ease the pain. There are small rewards, good ways of indicating your progress, and constant contextualization.

This little navigation appears inside of a module, a collection of lessons, code challenges, and quizzes that are like a course. The navigation has a ton of information packed into a tiny space with titles, content types, and location all wrapped together. I particularly like the use of the profile picture as the location marker - it’s instantly recognizable and helps reinforce that I’m making progress (Even in PHP)

Day 34 - Balsamiq's Lorem Ipsum

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When entering a paragraph in Balsamiq, typing “lorem” inserts a full paragraph of filler text.

Why it’s good: Balsamiq doesn’t do a ton, so it makes what it does do work very efficiently. Contextual suggestions don’t have to be brilliant as long as they support the workflow.

Day 33 - Skitch's Drag Tab

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When working in Skitch, there’s a small tab that when dragged, becomes a manipulatable version of your file. This file can be dragged and dropped into your file system.

Why it’s good: Skitch is generally a great excercise in doing something fast and getting out of the way. Its toolset is limited, and everything revolves around quickly grabbing something, annotating it, and getting it into your file system.

Skitch understands its own context, you typically boot it up in the middle of a task flow. Instead of requiring you to drive through a standard save dialog, Skitch gets that you’re probably already looking at what you want and where you want to put it, so it gives you the fastest way possible to accomplish that.

Day 32 - Google Map's Time Added

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When you are traveling and getting stuck in traffic, Google Maps now tease apart the time added by the traffic.

Why it’s good: When we were driving back from Cedar Point a few weeks ago, we noticed that our “time to home” kept spiking up. Normally we would just be consigned to sit in traffic, but the tools that Google now offers through maps gave us all of the information we needed to make decisions. While we could just trust that the suggested route is faster, the little badge helps prove the point, and makes the user feel like they have control over the situation.

These little badges have also been really helpful at helping contextualize the traffic that I deal with on a daily commute. Instead of just knowing “The traffic is bad,” Google now quantifies how bad the traffic is, enabling me to make the best decisions possible.

Day 31 - Confluence's Keyboard Shortcuts

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When working in Confluence, there are a number of shortcuts available to you at any given time. Confluence indicates these shortcuts with subtle hints, like underlining a single letter or including it in parenthesis in a tooltip.

Why it’s good: Keyboard shortcuts are the consummate expert’s tool. For any application, there’s inevitably a cheat sheet of keyboard shortcuts somewhere that indicates everything you can do with them. I even have an index card on my desk with a list of shortcuts for Trello while I’m learning them.

Confluence isn’t a tool that most people live in, so expecting the user to memorize all of keyboard shortcuts isn’t realistic. This subtle indication doesn’t get in the way, but it does tell me what things I can do quickly. Incidentally, I’ve learned the keyboard shortcuts incredibly quickly because they’re always present.
